<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Orientation of the train in relation to the direction of the LRBG</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2 bits</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Reverse</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Nominal</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2</td><td colspan="2">Unknown</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>3</td><td colspan="2">Spare</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.105 Q DIRTRAIN


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Direction of train movement in relation to the LRBG orientation</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2 bits</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Reverse</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Nominal</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2</td><td colspan="2">Unknown</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>3</td><td colspan="2">Spare</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.106 QDLRBG


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier telling on which side of the LRBG the estimated front end is</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2 bits</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Reverse</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Nominal</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2</td><td colspan="2">Unknown</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>3</td><td colspan="2">Spare</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.107 Q EMERGENCYSTOP


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier for emergency stop acknowledgement</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier to inform the RBC about the use of a conditional emergency stop by the on-board equipment. For an unconditional emergency stop, it is set to “not relevant”</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Conditional Emergency Stop accepted, with update of current EOA/LOA (ref 3.10.2.2)</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Conditional Emergency Stop accepted, with no update of current EOA/LOA (ref 3.10.2.2)</td></tr></table>

## ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td style='text-align: center;'>2</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Not Relevant (Unconditional Emergency Stop) (ref 3.10.2.3)</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>3</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Conditional Emergency Stop rejected because train has passed the emergency stop location (ref 3.10.2.2)</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.108 Q_ENDTIMER


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier to indicate whether end section timer information exists for the End section in the MA</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">No End section timer information</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">End section timer information to follow</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.109 Q_FRONT


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier for validity end point of profile element</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier to indicate if a speed limit given for a profile element is to be applied until the front of the train (no train length delay) or the end of the train (train length delay) has left the element</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Train length delay on validity end point of profile element.</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">No train length delay on validity end point of profile element</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.110 Q_GDIR


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier for gradient slope.</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">downhill</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">uphill</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.111 Q INFILL


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier to indicate whether a train is entering or exiting the radio infill area.</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3"></td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Enter</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Exit</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.112 Q_LENGTH


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier for train integrity status</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier, identifying the train integrity information available. The related safe train length information is given by L_TRAININT</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2 bits</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">No train integrity information available</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Train integrity confirmed by integrity monitoring device</td></tr></table>

<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td rowspan="2"></td><td style='text-align: center;'>2</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Train integrity confirmed by driver</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>3</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Train integrity lost</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.113 Q\_LGTLOC


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier for the specified report location</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">This qualifier tells whether the train has to report its position when the max safe front end or when the min safe rear end has over passed the location defined by D_LOC</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Min safe rear end</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Max safe front end</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.114 Q LINK


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Link Qualifier</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">This qualifier is used to mark a balise group as linked or unlinked.</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Unlinked</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Linked</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.115 Q_LOCACC


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Accuracy of the balise location</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">This Qualifier defines the absolute value of the accuracy of the Balise location (i.e., the value 63m identifies a location accuracy of +/- 63m)</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>6 bits</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0 m</td><td style='text-align: center;'>63 m</td><td style='text-align: center;'>1 m</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.116 Q LINKORIENTATION


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier for the direction of the linked balise group</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">Indicates whether the linked balise group will be overpassed by the train in nominal or reverse direction.</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">The balise group is seen by the train in reverse direction</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">The balise group is seen by the train in nominal direction</td></tr></table>

##### 7.5.1.117 Q LINKREACTION


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">linking reaction</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier for the reaction to be performed if a linking or a balise group message consistency problem occurs with the balise group linked to.</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>2 bits</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>00</td><td colspan="2">Train trip</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>01</td><td colspan="2">Apply service brake</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>10</td><td colspan="2">No Reaction</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>11</td><td colspan="2">Spare</td></tr></table>

## ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

<div style="text-align: center;">7.5.1.118 Q LOOPDIR</div>



<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier to indicate the direction of the loop</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">Indicates LOOP-reference direction in relation to EOLM direction</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Opposite</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Same</td></tr></table>

<div style="text-align: center;">7.5.1.118.0Q LSSMA</div>



<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier for the LSSMA display</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">This qualifier tells whether the on-board has to toggle on/off the display of the lowest supervised speed within the MA</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">Toggle off</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">Toggle on</td></tr></table>

###### 7.5.1.118.1 Q LXSTATUS


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">LX Protection Status</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">Indicates whether the LX is protected or not</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">LX is protected</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">LX is not protected</td></tr></table>

###### 7.5.1.118.2 Q MAMODE


<table border=1 style='margin: auto; width: max-content;'><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Name</td><td colspan="3">Qualifier to indicate the supervision of the beginning of the mode profile</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Description</td><td colspan="3">This qualifier defines whether the beginning of the mode profile shall be considered as the SvL, or if the SvL shall be derived from the movement authority.</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>Length of variable</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Minimum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Maximum Value</td><td style='text-align: center;'>Resolution/formula</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1 bit</td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td><td style='text-align: center;'></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2">Special/Reserved Values</td><td style='text-align: center;'>0</td><td colspan="2">derive the SvL from the MA</td></tr><tr><td style='text-align: center;'>1</td><td colspan="2">beginning of mode profile to be considered as the SvL</td></tr></table>

###### 7.5.1.118.3 Q MARQSTREASON

# ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

### 8.3 Introduction

#### 8.3.1 Scope and Purpose

8.3.1.1 This chapter defines the format and content of messages necessary for ERTMS/ETCS functions.

8.3.1.2 Concerning the transmission media, this chapter does not cover considerations such as medium-specific use constraints (e.g. distance between track-circuit and balise...), as well as functions (e.g. detection of balise reference, time and location stamp, identifying type of receiving balise, Key Management, Releasing/maintaining a radio connection...) and performance of the transmission media.

#### 8.3.2 Definitions

8.3.2.1 Transmission media considered hereafter are standard ERTMS/ETCS transmission media used for ETCS (Eurobalise, Euroradio and Euroloop).

8.3.2.2 A message includes user data (application level) and protocol data (depending on the transmission medium).

8.3.2.3 A Eurobalise message is the information sent by a balise group (i.e. the message is composed of one or several telegrams, sorted by balise number in the group (telegram from balise number 1 first), each telegram is transmitted by a Eurobalise). A Eurobalise telegram contains one header and an identified and coherent set of Packets.

---

# ERA *UNISIG* EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

### 8.4 Rules

#### 8.4.1 Common Rules

8.4.1.1 A message (Euroradio/Euroloop) or telegram (Eurobalise) is composed of

1. One Header.

2. When needed, a predefined set of variables (only for Radio),

3. When needed, a predefined set of Packets (only for Radio).

4. Optional Packets as needed by application.

8.4.1.2 The transmission order shall respect the order of data elements listed in the message format (from top to bottom).

8.4.1.3 The behaviour of the receiver shall not depend on the sequence of the Packets given by the message.

8.4.1.3.1 Exception for Infill information: The locations given in the packets following packet 136 (Infill Location Reference) shall be referred to the balise group indicated in such packet.

8.4.1.3.2 Note: orientations are in any case always referred to the directionality of balise group (balise transmission), directionality of loop (Euroloop transmission) or directionality of LRBG (radio transmission).

8.4.1.4 A track-to-train message shall contain at most one instance of the same packet type for the same direction.

8.4.1.4.1 Exception 1: A message can contain several packets 44 (Data used by applications outside the ERTMS/ETCS system).

8.4.1.4.2 Exception 2: A message can contain several packets 65 (Temporary Speed Restriction). In case of revocable TSRs, the identities of the corresponding temporary speed restrictions (variable  $ NID\_TSR $ ) transmitted in the same message shall be different.

8.4.1.4.3 Exception 3: A message can contain several packets 66 (TSR Revocation). The identities of the corresponding temporary speed restrictions (variable  $ NID\_TSR $ ) transmitted in the same message shall be different.

8.4.1.4.4 Exception 4: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain one packet 136 per balise telegram per direction. Each packet 136 indicates which part of that telegram is to be considered as part of the infill information. Multiple packets 136 in balises of a balise group shall have identical content per direction.

---

# ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

8.4.1.4.5 Exception 5: A message can contain several packets 88 (Level Crossing information). The identities of the corresponding Level Crossings (variable NID_LX) transmitted in the same message shall be different.

8.4.1.4.6 Exception 6: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain several packets 254 (default balise, loop or RIU information).

8.4.1.4.7 Exception 7: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain several packets 145 (Inhibition of balise group message consistency reaction).

8.4.1.4.8 Exception 8: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain several packets 0 (Virtual Balise Cover marker).

8.4.1.4.9 Exception 9: A message transmitted by a balise group can contain several packets 6 (Virtual Balise Cover order). The identities (pairs of variables  $ N_{ID\_VBCMK} $  and  $ N_{ID\_C} $ ) of the corresponding VBC transmitted in the same message shall be different.

8.4.1.5 A train-to-track message shall contain at most one instance of the same packet type.

8.4.1.5.1 Exception: A message can contain several packets 44 (Data used by applications outside the ERTMS/ETCS system).

8.4.1.6 Note: For the purposes of clause 8.4.1.4, when the same packet is transmitted by duplicated balises, this is considered to be only a single instance of the packet within the message. Justification: The on-board equipment will only use one of these duplicated telegrams (and therefore only one set of duplicated packets) to compose the balise group message (see 3.16.2.4.8.2).

---

# ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

#### 8.4.2 Rules for Eurobalise telegrams

8.4.2.1 The format of the telegram to be transmitted by each balise is as follows:

Number of bits in balise header: 50

8.4.2.2 The user information transmitted by a balise shall contain complete packets, i.e. splitting a packet between two balises is forbidden.

8.4.2.3 When used, the packet 0 shall be transmitted as the first packet of the telegram (i.e. it is appended to the header).

# ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

#### 8.4.3 Rules for Euroloop messages

8.4.3.1 The format of the message to be transmitted by each loop is as follows:

# ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

#### 8.4.4 Rules for Euroradio messages

8.4.4.1 The message identifier is unique (variable NID_MESSAGE).

8.4.4.1.1 All currently not defined message identifiers are reserved for future use and shall be considered as invalid values (i.e. like spare values) when received by the on-board equipment. Exception: reception of information only differing by Y with regards to the highest system version number X supported by on-board (refer to section 3.17.3.11 b)).

8.4.4.2 Each message shall indicate its own length through the use of the variable L_MESSAGE.

8.4.4.2.1 If the computed length of the message is not equal to the length given by L_MESSAGE, the entire message shall be rejected.

8.4.4.3 The messages shall be composed of predefined variables and packets.

8.4.4.4 For some messages, it shall be possible to add optional packets at the end of the message.

8.4.4.4.1 The track to train messages possibly including optional packets are listed hereafter:

8.4.4.4.2 The train to track message 136 (Train Position Report) and 157 (SoM Position Report) may optionally include the following packets:

a) Packet 4 (Error Reporting).

b) Packet 5 (Train running number).

c) Packet 44 (Data used by applications outside the ERTMS/ETCS system).

8.4.4.4.4 The train to track message 132 (MA request) may optionally include the following packet:

a) Packet 9 (Level 2/3 transition information)

8.4.4.5 If needed to obtain an integer number of bytes, padding shall be added at the end of the message.

# ERA * UNISIG * EEIG ERTMS USERS GROUP

### 9.3 Introduction

#### 9.3.1 Scope and Purpose

9.3.1.1 Chapter 9 lists a classification into categories of all the clauses in the chapters 1 to 8 of the SRS.

9.3.1.2 The purpose of this chapter is to ease the assessment of the compliance of an ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment with the SRS.

9.3.1.3 To that effect, this chapter comprehensively identifies which clauses contain requirements allocated to the ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment and conversely which ones do not, either because they contain requirements allocated to the ERTMS/ETCS trackside only or because they are of another type.

#### 9.3.2 Definitions

9.3.2.1 The following categories are used to classify each SRS clause:

a) ERTMS/ETCS on-board requirement: a clause containing requirement(s) that must be fulfilled by a SRS compliant ERTMS/ETCS on-board

b) ERTMS/ETCS trackside requirement: a clause containing requirement(s) that must be fulfilled by a SRS compliant ERTMS/ETCS trackside, in case the corresponding function is implemented

c) Definition: a clause that is a necessary prerequisite to the correct interpretation of requirement(s) or without which requirement(s) cannot be unambiguously interpreted

d) Informative: a clause that helps the reader to better understand the context or the justification of requirement(s)

e) Others: a clause that does not belong to any of the above categories

Throughout the SRS, the requirements are identified as sentences using the keyword "shall". However:

a) In section 9.4, tables are identified as a single entity through a reference based on the accompanying clause number. They can be classified as ERTMS/ETCS onboard and/or trackside requirements even if they do not include the keyword "shall".

b) Elements of the ERTMS/ETCS language (radio messages, packets and variables, see chapters 7 and 8) are also described with tables. The numbered titles (i.e. the name of the element preceded by a clause number) together with their associated table are considered as single entities and are classified as both ERTMS/ETCS onboard and trackside requirements, even if they do not include the keyword "shall" either.

9.3.2.3 Amongst the categories listed in 9.3.2.1 only the two first ones can be combined, in case a requirement equally applies to both ERTMS/ETCS on-board equipment and ERTMS/ETCS trackside or in case two unambiguously distinguishable on-board and trackside requirements are kept together in the concerned clause for readability reasons.
